DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher, Gold Mixed
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished slightly higher Tuesday against most major currencies but slipped against the Japanese yen in quiet global foreign exchange dealings. Gold prices were narrowly mixed. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid for gold as of 4 p.m. EST of $411.75 a troy ounce, down $1 from Monday's late bid. Earlier, gold gained on New York's Commodity Exchange and in Europe. Currency analysts said the pace of trading has slowed in recent days as the yearend holidays approach and traders try to protect whatever gains they may have made for the year. ``We are in a holiday trading period, and a lot of bank traders are not as active as they had been,'' said James Merrill, senior international economist for the financial services company McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei. He said the currency markets appeared to be largely unaffected by new government reports of a decline in housing starts and a slightly bigger-than-expected rise in consumer prices last month. The 4.7 percent decline in housing starts indicated some sluggishness in the economy, weakness that many analysts feel the Federal Reserve will eventually respond to by lowering interest rates. But the 0.4 percent rise in consumer prices was slightly stronger than analysts had expected, and could delay the Fed's credit relaxation. Dollar traders were also wary about making big commitments until they get some indication from the two-day meeting of Federal Reserve policymakers on what course they have charted for monetary policy over the next few weeks. If the Fed moves to lower interest rates, the dollar could be hurt since falling interest rates cut the returns foreigners get on dollar-denominated investments. The dollar's decline against the yen was attributed to speculation that the Bank of Japan may soon raise its key lending rate. Japanese authorities denied the rumors of an imminent rate hike, but speculation persisted that an increase would eventually be necessary to shore up the yen. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.42 Japanese yen to close at 143.80 yen. Later, in London, the dollar was quoted at 143.80 yen. The dollar fell to 143.65 yen in New York from 143.725 yen late Monday. The dollar gained against the British pound. In London, the pound fell to $1.6005 from $1.6020 late Monday. In New York, the pound fell to $1.6010 from $1.60685. Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.7365 West German marks, up from 1.7210; 1.5565 Swiss francs, up from 1.5410; 5.9275 French francs, up from 5.8800; 1,289.25 Italian lire, up from 1,285.00; and 1.16085 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16075. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.7365 West German marks, up from 1.7245; 1.5615 Swiss francs, up from 1.5480; 5.9300 French francs, up from 5.8890; 1.9575 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9455; 1,291.25 Italian lire, up from 1,289.25; and 1.1613 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1610. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery edged up 10 cents a troy ounce to $411.90. Earlier, gold rose to $413.75 a troy ounce in London from $409.25 late Monday; to $414.00 in Zurich from $408.50 and to $412.80 in Hong Kong from $410.97. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery fell 3.8 cents an ounce to $5.527. Silver rose in London to a late bid of $5.57 a troy ounce from $5.55 late Monday.
